Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth,and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening befor.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon,the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arrivving in London at the very conveniant hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is L22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
The Sea fares are:-
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
To The East.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 13, 1905.

div.head: RENTS IN CAIRO.
div.p: Some time ago our columns contained a correspondence in which the question whether a young Englishman could live in Cairo at L10 a month was argued with eloquence and vigour. We should now like to bring before the notice of our readers the results of the raising of rents in Cairo as far as they touch young British officials, and others of the same class, and whose standard of life is the same. The average young Englishman of this type, when he first comes to Egypt,goes to a pension for some little time and then, if he can afford it, takes a flat with one or more friends. Well and good if his pay allows of it, but there are plenty of young Englishmen whose pay is not high and who cannot afford a comfortable and healthy flat. A man drawing anything under L30 a month had better stay in a pension, for, if he takes a cheap flat in the less-known quarters of Cairo, he runs a risk of catching typhoid or of finding himself in an uncongenial neighborhoood.

As for the pensions,there are two or three good and thoroughly well-managed English pensions, if not more; but in all the prices are rather high and will never get any lower. The increased price of food, the rise in rents,which forces those who manage pensions to heighten their charges, and the growing demands of the native servant,all tell on the pocket of the young man with a fixed income. Now if he wishes to go to a good pension of the second order- we do not wish to name names or advertise any of these establishments- he may fall on his feet. But he may also find that in his pension are persons whom he does not care to know, and whose very presence under the same roof may injure him. A young employe of any business or commercial establishment has to be careful, not for social reasons, for, snobbish though we are as a nation,the average Englishman does not suppose that his subordinates are to be judged and condemned because they happen to sleep under the same roof and to dine in the same room as undesirable characters, but because Egypt posseses more than a fair share of unscrupulous and needy persons of many nationalities- our own not excepted- who are on the watch for the young man from home. The slightest indiscretion, even a refusal to discuss a subject, may give the wily enquirer a valuable "tip," and therefore the bank manager and his fellows like to see their subordinates staying in establishments where the man with an axe to grind is rare.

But these establishments, as we have pointed out, grow dearer and take more of a man's pay. To the young permanent official this does not matter quite so much, for he comes out to make a career and to retire with a pension, and ought to be able to wait and at least simulate contentment, though if promotion is slow or his Under-Secreatary of State or departmental chief forgets to recommend that his pay be raised before the new financial year begins- and once upon a time a chief forgot to recommend a single man in his department and his staff fumed for months, having been promised mountains and marvels- this simulation is hard to keep up. But the young employe of a bank or business house, who has to keep up appearances like the rest, to pay calls, dress,return bachelor hospitality, and join clubs, remarks with grief that while rents and prices rise wages do not rise at all. The economic books say they do; it may be true in Europe, and it may be true of certain classes here, but it is not true of the class of which we speak. Can any of our readers give a recipe for the "simple life" (with appearances saved and thrown in) and a credit balance monthly, or is it impossible to eat your cake and have it too?

div.head: THE RUSSIAN CRISIS. REVOLT OF PRISONERS. HOLY SYNOD'S APPEAL.
div.p: St. Petersburg, November 11.

Martial law has been proclaimed at Kronstadt. The corps of Marine Cadets here is in a state of extreme excitement. The cadets insist upon the band playing ‘ the "Marseillaise" on every opportunity, singing to the music ribald words insulting the Tsar.
(Reuter)
Kishineff, November 11.
Yesterday evening the prisoners in the gaol revolted en masse and set fire to the prison. The troops arrived and fired, killing 22 and wounding many.
(Reuter)
St. Petersburg, November 12.

The last of the Kronstadt mutineers have surrendered. The Holy Synod has issued an address to the people begging them to cease attacking and murdering landed proprietors and Jews, and to avoid civil war. It further urges them to inaugurate an era of peace and tranquillity. Martial law has been proclaimed throughout Poland, where the authorities fear that an insurrection is being organised. M. Witte has received telegrams from various parts of Poland demanding full autonomy, including a Diet at Warsaw, elected by universal suffrage. M. Witte informed a Polish deputation that he is in favor of autonomous administration, but opposed to political autonomy.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE NEW CABINET
div.p: St. Petersburg, November 11.

The Minister of Justice remains in office, and the Cabinet is therefore complete except the Ministers of the Interior and Public Instruction, seeing that the Ministers of War Marine, Foreign Affairs, and the Court do not form part of the Cabinet according to the plan of re-organisation of 26th October.

div.head: POWERS’ NAVAL DEMONSTRATION. ITALY AND TURKEY.
div.p: Rome, November 12.

It is semi-officially explained that Italy’s cooperation with the Powers in the naval demonstration is not inspired by any ill-feeling towards Turkey, but by a belief in the necessity of financial control in Macedonia. The squadrons will probably meet at Piraeus.

div.head: RELIEF OF UNEMPLOYED. QUEEN’S CONTRIBUTION TO FUND.
div.p: London, November 11.
The Queen has given £2,000 to the unemployed fund, and appeals to all charitable persons in the Empire to relieve the starving daring the winter.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE CAIRO FRERES CASE. FORMER FINDING REVERSED.
div.p: Paris November ll.

The Court of Cassation has reversed the finding of the Aix Court, similar to that of the Cairo Consular Court, in the libel suit brought by the director of the Christian Schools in Cairo, admitting the action of the local director and not that of the General Superior of the Congregation.
(Havas)

div.head: DR NANSEN. NORWEGIAN MINISTER IN LONDON.
div.p: London, November 11.
The explorer Dr. Nansen has been appointed Norwegian Minister here.
(Reuter)

div.head: BRITISH SQUADRON’S VISIT TO NEW YORK.
div.p: New YORK November 11.

The visit of the British Squadron to New York is affording an occasion for every kind of international courtesy. Prince Louis of Battenberg is producing an excellent impression by his unaffected geniality.
(Reuter)

div.head: french ministry.
div.p: Paris, November 11.
M. Etienne has succeeded M. Berteaux as Minister of War.
(Reuter)
Paris November 12.
M. Efienne has been appointed Minister of War, M. Dubief of the Interior, and M. Trouillet of Commerce. The other Ministers retain their portfolios.
(Havas)

div.head: KING ALFONSO IN VIENNA.
div.p: Berlin, November 12.
King Alfonso has left for Vienna.
(Havas)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Harmonia Club.
A successful afternoon dance was given at the Harmonia Club, Cairo, on Saturday afternoon.
Khedive's Accession Fete.
The first list of subscriptions towards the celebration of the anniversary of the Khedive's accession amounts to L.E. 133.
Dragoman Tariff.
The Governor of Suez has issued a new tariff for dragomans and public guides, which comes into force in a week.
Land and Mortgage Co. of Egypt (Ltd.)
The directors have declared an interim dividend at the rate of 10 p.c. for the six months ended Sept. 30 last.
Killed by a Buffalo.
A native boy was tending a buffalo near El Fashn Markaz on Saturday, when the animal turned upon the lad and gored him to death.
Egyptian Estates, Limited.
Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi have purchased a fine block of land in an excellent position in Cairo from the Egyptian Estates, Limited.
Suez Canal.

From the 7th to the 9th inst 24 vessels passed through the Canal, of which 17 were British, 1 German, 2 French, 2 Dutch, 1 Austrian, 1 Greek. The total amount received in dues from the 1st to the 9th inst was frs. 2,965,670.93.
Nile Valley Operations.
October crushing:—The 5-stamp battery ran 21.5 days, crushing 410 tons of ore, yielding 198 ozs of gold over the plates, valued at £720 sterling. The total footage development was 208 ft.
Ministry of The Interior.

Mr. J. de M. Johnson and Mr. Arthur Thomas Lloyd have been appointed by special decision to be sub-inspectors of the Ministry of the Interior, with pay at the rate of L.E. 240 per annum. These appointments are probationary.
Gaolbird Captured.

Hussein el Sayid, who was condemned in 1893 to 15 years' imprisonment with hard labour, for the murder of Sheikh Abdel Ghani Osman, omdeh of Sheikh Fadl, and had escaped from prison, living for several years in the country unknown to the police, has been recaptured and put in prison again.
Village Murder.

A native named Ali Abon Shahbeh of Mahallat Manouf, was found murdered on the 8th inst. in that village. An enquiry into the circumstances of the crime has led the Tantah authorities to suspect the omdeh’s cousin and the latter's servant of the murder. The men’s clothes were found to be stained with blood.
Royal Anniversary.

Saturday being the birthday of H.M.King Victor Emmanuel III., the Gouvernorat, Consulates, and Agency flaw their national flags and the Italian dolours were much in evidence in the streets of Cairo. Visits were exchanged between Count A. Gonzaga and H.E. Boutros Pasha Ghali, Minister for Foreign Affairs, and a reception was held at the Italian Agency, which was largely attended.
Credit Franco-Egyptien.

Mr. Petcovich, sub-manager of the Credit Lyonnais at Alexandria, has been appointed manager of the Credit Franco-Egyptien at a salary of £3,000 a year. We congratulate the Credit Franco-Egyptien on the appointment, for the business capabilities of Mr. Petcovich are well known, and the acquisition of this gentleman as director of the Credit augurs well for the sound financial lines on which it will be run. Restoration of Convent Nungovich Bey has handed to Mgr. Photina, Patriarch of Alexandria, the sum of £100 as a contribution towards the reconstruction of St George’s convent, which was burnt some time ago. He has also opened a credit of £500 at the Patriarchate for the same purpose. It is stated that M. Karam, of Alexandria, has generously offered to supply all the timber necessary for the reconstruction of the convten.
Khedivial Geographical Society

Two new bulletins have just been issued by the Khedivial Geographical Society, numbers 7 and 8 of the sixth series of these publications. The most interesting article is a study of the physical geography of the cataract at Assouan by Mr. Fourtan. It is enriched by some remarkable photographic reproductions of the rooks at Salouganarte. Dr. Bonola Bey contributes a note on Egypt and Nubia from the memoirs of Santoni and there are articles on Moslem explorers by Mahmoud Salem Bey, Feudal and Patriarchal customs in Abyssinia by Dr. Lincoln de Castro, and some impressions of a trip in German East Africa by Dr. Jaeger.

div.head: NIAM NIAM EXPEDITION. GOOD SERVICE LIST.
div.p: His Excellency the Sirdar has just published \ list of officers, N.C.O’s, and men whose names had been brought to the notion of he Khedive for their good services in the recent operations against the Niam-Niams. The list includes the names of the late Miralai Boulnois Bey, commanding the expedition, the late Kaimakam Fell Bey, Intelligence officer, Bimbashi Rawson, Kaimakam Sutherland Bey, and one native officer, all of the Staff, Bimbashi Bethell, one native officer, and one soldier of the Artillery, Bimbashi Percival Bey, D.S.O., one native officer, and one soldier of the Camel Corps, Kaimakam Carter Bey, three native officers, and five N.C.O’s. and men of the 9th Sudanese, Kaimakam Gordon Bey, two native officers, and two N.C.O's and men of the 10th Sudanese, Bimbashi Ryan, D.S.O., one native officer, and two men of the 15th Sudanese, Kaimakam Bray Bey, Kaimakam Riven Bey, and Bimcbashi Brakemridge, and two native officers of the Medical Corps, and Bimbashi Flint and three native officers of the Transport.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: Ibrahim Pasha Fathi, Director of the Recruiting Department, has been appointed Emir El Hag, and Mohamed Bey Wahbi, an official in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, treasurer, for the present year’s pilgrimage.

div.head: TWO MOROCCAN VISITORS.
div.p: Sid Mohamed El Mackry, son of the Moroccan Finance Minister, and Sid Mohamed El-Benani, engineer in the Moroccan Government, have recently arrived in Cairo. After spending several days in the Capital they will proceed to the Hedjaz, on the pilgrimage.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The Council of Ministers will meet next Saturday morning, at Abdeen Palace, under the presidency of the Khedive.

div.head: FINANCE MINISTRY.
div.p: The drawing up of the new project elaborated by the Ministry of Finance relative to the classification by degree of Government fficials, will be finished by the end of March, and it will come into force as from the 1st January next.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H. H. the Khedive is expected to pass five or six days at Montazah and during his stay to inspect his properties at Mariout.

div.head: THE LATE ME. MOLTENI.
div.p: The body of the late Me. Molteni has been successfully embalmed and will be conveyed to Cairo station on Monday afternoon, the family of the deceased having decided that the burial should take place in Italy.

div.head: CAIRO TRAMWAYS.
div.p: There is no truth in the statement of a contemporary that a misunderstanding has occurred between the Cairo Tramway Company and the Ministry of Public Works oh the subject of the new carriages, with first-class compartments, which it is intended to place very shortly on all the lines. There has been some delay in their delivery, but it is expected that they will be running by the new year, These carriages, which have a compartment for first-class passengers in front, another for ladies at the end, and accommodation for the second class in the centre, should prove a great boon to those residents who are compelled to use the tramcars several times daily between their homes and offices, and we congratulate M. Dessalles, the energetic manager, on this innovation. The company will in a short time begin the laying of the now extension from the present terminus at Boulac to the Boole des Arts et Metiers. Some delay has occurred in beginning the work on account of the difficulties the company has encountered from the owners of the properties to be expropriated for this purpose.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL, PORT SAID.
div.p: This well-known hostelry has been sold by Mr. Klingler, the proprietor and manager of the Continental Hotel in Cairo, to Mr. Henri Chamoulleau, former proprietor of the Khedivial Hotel at Alexandria, who will enter into possession on the 15th November. During the four years that the hotel has been in possession of the former gentleman he has succeeded in forming a high-class clientele, which no doubt Mr. Chamoulleau will not only retain but increase, since his reputation as an hotelier has long been established. Daring the summer a large sum of money has been spent on alterations and improvements at the Savoy Hotel, which will add greatly to the comfort of visitors. The whole of the shops facing the quay have been removed and replaced by a fine dining saloon and bar opening on the sea front and supported by massive marble columns. The additions include 32 newly-built bedrooms, which bring up the total to 74. Mr. Klingler lately obtained an extension of the lease from the Messageries Maritimes, who are the owners of the whole large block of buildings in which the hotel is situated.

div.head: PIRACY IN THE RED SEA. H.M.S. FOX’S MISSION.
div.p: Details of the fighting which occurred at Hodeida, in the Yemen, when the British cruiser Fox was at that place a few weeks ago in connection with the pursuit and punishment of the pirates who bad attacked British dhows, have just been received. Claims were lodged with the Porte in regard to these outrages, and the Pox was despatched to the Yemen coast in order to see that the local authorities carried out the British demands, arrested and punished the guilty persons, and destroyed the pirate dhows. The British cruiser co-operated with the local Turkish authorities in the accomplishment of these objects. It was found that the pirates bad moored their dhows at a place called Khor Gbu’eifaka, which was not easy for the Turks to attack and that the former had mounted guns round the cove where the pirate chips were lying. A stiff fight occurred, in which the pirates lost twenty-five killed and a large number of wounded. A launch belonging to the Fox went aground and was lost, and one British sailor was slightly wounded.

div.head: BAGOURIAH canal.
div.p: In consequence of the low level of the Nile it has been derided not to close the Bagourish Canal during December and January, as previously notified.

div.head: LAUNCHES FOR THE NILE.
div.p: Four car-loads of power launches were shipped from St. Joseph, Mich., on the 20th ult. to the order of the Egyptian Government for use on the River Nile.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL COMMISSION.
div.p: Sir Charles Hartley and Sir John Wolfe Barry have left London for Paris to attend the annual meeting of, the International Technical Commission of the Suez Canal, on which they are the British representatives.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL COUPONS.
div.p: The board of directors of the Suez Canal have fixed the rate of the coupons due on January 1 next, at follows : Actions de Capital, gross 35 fr. Actions de Capital, net 50.408 fr. Actions de Jouissance, gross 42.50 fr. Actions de Jouissance, net 88.782 fr. Pounders' Shares, grots 23.943 fr. Founders' Shares, net 29.005 frs. Coupons can now be presented.

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: M.M. Fourneron and Sampaolo have returned from their inspection of the Matana, Arment, and Nag Hamadi factories with a very large collection of documents for their next report, which, however, can hardly be completed in time for Thursday's hearing. The report promisee to be the most important and interesting of the series and will doubtless give rise to vigorous discussion. At the request of the Hon. A. J.Davey, the bearing of the action brought by M. Poutrel has been fixed for Tuesday, 14th inst.

div.head: EGYPTIAN SALT AND SODA CO.
div.p: On Saturday last, the first consignment of oilcake made at the Kafr Zayat factory since the establishment of the new regime of the Salt and Soda Company was shipped from Alexandria for England by the S.S. Mariner, chartered by Messrs. Barber and Son. A large quantity of machinery, plant for the manufacture of caustic sods, has been dispatch ed from Alexandria to the Wady Natron.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LAND AND GENERAL TRUST.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes to ask how it is that we published an authorised denial of the rumour that Mr. A. Hooker had retiree from the Egyptian Land and General Trust Limited, when in a letter from Crooksbank Pasha, addressed to the Editor of the “Egyptian Gazette,” the Pasha alluded to Mr. Hooker as ex-managing director. The reply to this question is that Mr. Hooker has resigned the post of managing director of the company, but he has not resigned his position on the board, and is therefore still a director.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: Daring the absence on leave of El Lewa St. George C.Henry Pasha,c B., Adjutant General. El Miralai Asser Bey, Commandant, Khartoum Station, has taken over the duties of Acting Adjutant General. El Bimbashi Moore,Junior Inspector, Kaseala province, has been granted leave of absence till December 31.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Carib Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left London on Saturday, 11th inst, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 97th inst The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Congo from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due here tomorrow. The S.S. Sailor Prince, from Alexandria arrived at Manchester on Saturday last.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA WATER SUPPLY REPLY TO “ALEXANDRIAN. ’’ To THE Editor of the Egyptian Gazette
div.p: Sir,—In your paper of yesterday you publish a letter under the above heading signed "Alexandrian,” containing certain malicious statements, which, if true, would not only reflect very seriously on me and my colleagues, past and present, on the board of the Alexandria Water Company, Ltd., but also on the character of many high officials of the Egyptian Government, who, during a long series of years, have represented the Government on the board of that company. Your correspondent says "it was discovered " that the company were charging the double of what they were legally entitled to for a " girbeh of water.” This statement is absolutely false ; the Water Company never has sold water at any higher price than they were legally entitled to. In the autumn of 1878 the waterworks of Alexandria were offered for sale in London, by a man of the highest integrity, then Minister of Finance to the Egyptian Government, under certain conditions, and one of the most attractive of these conditions was, that a certain branch of the service known as the Sakkas, or water carriers, service, brought in a net revenue of £12,000 a year ; this was not an estimated revenue, but one which had been realised for many years by the Egyptian Government itself, at the price at which it had sold the water, and proposed to transfer and did subsequently transfer, to its purchaser, the Water Company, by contract of sale, the right to continue the sale of water on the same condition, and at the same tariff as that in use by the Government during the many years it had worked the undertaking. Not only is this confirmed by contract, but the gentleman to whom I above refer, is still living, and not only can, but would contradict me, if anything I say in this matter is not strictly true, The Water Company rotated this right until 1894, when it gave it up not as your correspondent says, because it was an extortion, but as the result of an agreement with the Municipality of Alexandria, who offered in exchange for it a new system of filtration subject only to a contribution of L.E. 10,000 by the Water Company, and not only this, but they gave the company the right to sell water by meter, a right which led to complications, reference to which would tale up too much of your space. Not only was it the first duty of the Government representatives on our board to assure themselves that the Water Company was acting in accordance with its legal rights, bat I am in a position to say, without fear of contradiction, that one and all of these gentlemen conscientiously did their duty in this respect There are several other inaccuracies in the letter under notice, which I could easily refute, but will not weary your readers by doing so at present. I write only in my own name, and without prejudice to any action in the matter which my colleagues may decide to take ; they are men as well known as any in Alexandria, and it requires no testimony of mine to defend them ; but in memory of those with whom I formerly had the honor of being associated, and who have gone from this world and are no longer able to defend themselves, I will, say, that it is a disgraceful action to endeavor to sully their names by such false insinuations; for they were honorable men, who,under trying circumstances, did the best which could be expected of them for the general good. I do not know who your correspondent "Alexandrian” may be, nor have I the slightest wish to make his acquaintance, for, in my opinion, a man who would publish the malicious statements he has made, on a subject oh which be shows that he is profoundly ignorant, is beneath contempt.—I remain, etc., E. Cornish, A director of the Alexandria Water; Company, Limited. Alexandria, 12th November.

div.head: I. O. G. T. BLUE CAPS' PRIDE LODGE M107.
div.p: The above lodge held its opening session list week under favorable circumstances at Mustapha Pasha barracks, Alexandria, Bro. Charles Neill, V. T., presiding. After the transaction of the ordinary business of the lodge four initiations took place. Another friend was put on proposition. The lodge deputy urged the officers to do their utmost to keep the members together, and try and introduce new members to the Order. He hoped members would use their influence In the several departmental corps in Alexandria and swell the lodge. Work is required and not words, and he had not the least doubt that if brothers and sisters put their shoulders to the wheel, success would assuredly follow. The programme for the evening was the reading of “Temperance Cuttings.” Several members contributed. A debate followed in which Bros. Will, Ireland, Gervine, and Miller took part The meeting was duly closed by Bro. Neill, V.T, at 9 p.m. A regular session will be held on Tuesday next at 7 o'clock. Friends are cordially invited on the "good of order” programme.

div.head: A FRENCHMAN IN THESUDAN. HIS IMPRESSIONS.
div.p: M. E. Sulesses, director of the railway in French Guinea, has just returned to Paris from an official visit to Africa, during which be inspected all the railways now working on this continent, and saw a good deal of the Sudan and Egypt It is satisfactory to note for the future good relations of France and England in Africa that M. Salesses is an Anglophila He was presented to all the British officials in the course of his itinerary, and received the greatest assistance from their hands. His speaks particularly well of Sir Reginald Wingate— as, indeed, do all his compatriots. The Sirdar has known how to make himself extremely liked by the French because of his tact and consideration. M. Salesses exchanged a few words with Lord Cromer, and was impressed with the power of the man, even in so short an interview. As to the treatment of the natives by the British Administration, M. Salessies regards it somewhat in the light of mistaken kindness. The native is a child, and must be treated as such. Occasionally it is necessary to show firmness. You cannot apply all the ideas of Western justice to him. The judicial branch must not bo separated from the political and executive. There is no division of, labour amongst the native Africans. The potter digs his own clay ; the bootmaker is a tanner. And so the Commissioner in charge of a district should himself bo able to apply the law. Justice must be swift The native does not understand being punished three months after the commission of a crime. Three months is too long for his memory— he has forgotten all about the offence.” M. Salesses shares the view of Lord Cromer that the Cape-to-Cairo railway can very properly utilise a steamboat service on the lakes and the White Nile to connect its sections. He thinks that Germany should strike a bargain with England over the lease of a atrip of land between Tanganyika and Victoria Nyanza. Such a cession of territory would work no prejudice to German interests; on the contrary, the communication afforded by the railway would be highly profitable to the colony.

div.head: THE NEW SUDAN RAILWAY.
div.p: The railway line in the neighbourhood of Suakin has been washed away on two occasions lately in several places. It has now been repaired. Macaulay Bey and Drury Bey are expected at Suakin this week from Cairo.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: We see by the "Morning Post” of the. 4th just that a marriage has been arranged between Lord George Seymour, R.N., youngest son of the Marquis and Marchioness of Hertford, and Miss Norah Skipwith, only daughter of the late Mr. Archibald Peyton-Skiptwith and of Mrs. It. Curtis Toogood, 87, Cadogan-gardens, and niece of Admiral Sir Massie BlomfieldtK.C.M.G. Lord George Saymour is first cousin of Count Gleichen, formerly of the Military Intelligence Department, Egyptian Army.

Mr. Somera Clarke, the architect to St Paul’s Cathedra], is at present engaged in a study of the proposed restoration of St Mark’s Church, Alexandria. He is the guest of Admiral Sir Massie and Lady Blomfield.
We are sorry to hear that Lady Blomfield has been suffering from a sharp attack of influenza, and is still very weak.
Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of Alexandria City Police, was among the passengers who arrived by the Austrian mail this morning.
Chitty Bey returned from Cairo yesterday evening.
Mohamed Mahmoud Suleiman Effendi, sub-inspector to the Ministry of the Interior, has been appointed private secretary to the Adviser of the Ministry.
The well-known post and dramatist Sharkri Ghanem is expected to arrive at Cairo on the 27th inst.

Mr. J. Pearce-Hill, of the ET.C„Alexandria, is due to arrive at Port Said by the S.S. Pegn on Wednesday, on his return from leave Mr. Pearce Hill's reputation as an amateur entertainer is well-known, and his many friends here will be glad to bear that he has made arrangements for the production of a comic opera which has proved a great success both in America and England, and the "plot" of which is laid in Egypt To his popular ventriloquial show Mr. Pearce Hill has made several additions, and has also perfected a little invention of his own, whereby be is enabled not only to sing a duet with the assistance of "Mr,. and Mrs. Sawdust,” but play the accompaniment on the piano at the same time.

div.head: INTERESSANTE QUESTION DE DROIT.
div.p: Les syndics de la faillite d'une maison de commerce declaree a l'etranger par le Tribunal du siege principal de la dite maison de commerce peuveut-ils attaquer par voie de la tierce opposition un autre jugement posterieur qui a declare en Egypte la faillite de la meme maison de commerce au siege de sa succursale? Peuveut-ils en suite de la recevabilite de leur action demander l'annulation du second jugement basee sur l'incompetence du Tribunal qui l'a rendu?

Tellle est la question qui a ete plaidee samedi devant le tribunal mixte du Caire. Me Martin, pour les syndics de Beyrouth, a developpe en droit la theoriede l'unite et de l'universalite de la faillite.
Jugement a huitaine.

div.head: WALKER &MEIMARACHI. AN INCREASE OF CAPITAL
div.p: The eighth annual general meeting of Walker and Meimarachi, Limited, was heldon the 30th ult. at the offices,65, Londonwall, London, E.C., Mr. James Greenlees (the chairman) presiding.
The notice calling the meeting having been read,

The Chairman said: It is with pleasure that I rise to address you to-day. All those present have doubtlwss perused the dirctors' report to the shareholders, and we will therefore take it as read. Those shareholders who have attended our annual meetings have heard from my lips more about the progress of the company since its inception, some years ago, than has appeared in the formal reports, and they will therefore not have been surprised when they learnt that the directors, in continuation of their consistent policy of harbouring our cash resources, had decidedto advise the shareholders to declare this year an ordinary dividend of 1 per cent. increase upon that of last year; it is therefore proposedthat a five per cent. dividend be declared, payable on January 15 next. Reference to the balancesheet shows that the company could easily have paid more than this amount; but it has been considered wiser to proceed with caution.As time goes on and the prosperity of Egypt advances- and, let us hope, that of the company likewise- increased divideds will doubtless be paid to the ordinary shareholders. And this leads me to a few remarks upon the general condition of the company's financial aspect. The accounts show that, in addition to paying the usual 6 1/2 per cent. preference share dividend amounting to L8,125, the board have written off the balance of L3,677 5s. 8d. stading to the credit of fixtures and fittings and L787 13s. 5d. has been carried to reserve. We are advised by the managing director that the value of the stock is even greater than theamount at which it stands in our books. The amount of sundry debtors represents a slight increase upon last year, which is to be expected, considering the increased volume of trade.Without undue self-congratulation, we venture to believe that there are few trading companies outside the United Kingdom which can boast of so satisfactory a financial position as Walker and Meimarachi, taking into consideration the fiscal condition of the country in which the company carries on its trade. The directors do not take the credit of this satisfactory state of affairs entirely to themselves.Had they not had the active co-operation of both the preference and ordinary shareholders in the past- and particularly of the ordinary shareholders- this company could not have reached its present stage of development. We recently had occasion to prepare account showing certain aggregate returns of the amounts which the company has dealt with since the shareholders first met together to pass the accounts.

It will probably surprise you, as it has suprised us, when we tell you that the total amount of net profits of trading in Egypt since our incorporation has reached the very respectable total of L125,941 8s. 6d., and we paid in preference dividends L58, 570 5s. 9d. We have written off goodwill, fixtures, and fittings and preliminary expenses L28,405.Our reserve fund stands at L5,451 5s. 10d., and we have paid away some L16,062 in ordinary dividends. It is true that in the years of depression following the Sudan War the shareholders confirmed the policy of conserving the company's assets and passed the ordinary dividend, and the company is now reaping the benefit of your prudent policy. These figures speak more eloquently than any words of mine as to the soundness of the business which has been built up. Perhaps I may say that I now come to the most satisfactory, and at the same time the personal, side of the affairs of the company, so far as the members of your board are concerned. For years past your directors have been painfully aware, as you all know only too well, that the company's operations and extensions have been greatly hampered by want of adequate working capital. Notwithstanding the most urgent instructions to the executive in Egypt to curtail the stock and to reduce the amount of customers' outstanding accounts, it has not been found possible to do so without great detriment to the company's trade. Month after month the strongest representations have been made to this effect to the managing director, who has at all times shown the shareholders' representations the utmost courtesy and a desire to conform to such a policy; but the fact remains that, so far as out customers are concerned, credit, and very long credit, must bbe given,and we are advised that without such credit Walker and Meimarachi might as well close its stores and liquidate. It redounds greatly to the ability of the managing director, the general manager, and other members of the staff that up to the present the annual amount of bad debts has been surprisingly small. It may be that in Mr. Meimarachi we have a man possessed of a quite unique knowledge of the financial standing of every individual customer, or it may be due to some other cause unknown to us; but we prefer to believe that it is due to the able business ability and ever-constant supervision of our managing director.

The large amount of stock carried has also had our consideration; but here, again,our representatives definitely advise us that it can only be reduced with the prospect of the greatest danger to the company's trade; indeed,increased stock has always shown increased profits.These are indeed weighty matters, and as such have had more than usual serious attention of the board. Reports have from time to time reached the board from shareholders and customers that the company's premises were inconvenient and the stock inadequate, and so strong because the representations that it was decided to ask Mr.Drower to visit Cairo, and report specially upon these and other matters. Mr. Drower's report proved beyond a questioon of doubt that more commodious premises must be forthwith acquired. The difficult, however,was how this was to be accomplished. As, no doubt, most of you are aware, the value of land in and around Cairo has risen to almost a phenomenal extent, and during the last few years has doubled, and in some cases even trebled, its value. Having regard to these facts,it was felt that if additional working capital was to be forthcoming, it must be constituents in Egypt who had participated in the extraordinary prosperity of the country, rather than from our English shareholders. Our Cairo lawyer and one of our largest shareholders (Mr. Carton de Wiart) attended the board, and fully confirmed Mr. Drower's representations. The directors therefore determined that Mr. Luning should proceed to Egypt for the purpose of ascertaining the pulse of the capitalists on the spot. While in no way wishing to minimise the efforts of Mr. Luning and his subsequent success, still, the fact remains that had not the shareholders loyally seconded the policty of your board in past years, in strengthening our financial position, we believe that it would not have been possible to raise L100,000 additional working capital, except at very onerous rates. Still, it has been done,and we congratulate the shareholders accordingly, as we are certain, in our own minds, that without this capital the continuation of past successes could not be accomplished. We shall therefore be asking you, at the extraordinary general meeting to be held at the conclusion of the present,to vote unhesitatingly for the proposed increase of capital.Mr. Nungovich, the gentleman who has undertaken the responsibility of guaranteeing the L100,000, stipulates that he shall have the option of subscribing yet another L100,000 working capital at par, together with the right to claim L100,000 debentures carrying 5 per cent. interest, the latter to be secured upon the land and building which it is proposed to erect upon some central and convenient site in the very centre of business Cairo.

We have been given to understand that Mr. Nungovich has associated with him in the development of the present scheme some of the most able financiers in Egypt, and, for certain, we know that he has with him heart and soul his old friend and compatriot, your managing director (Mr. Meimarachi).The success of the scheme, therefore, appears to be assured. But there is, as I have already foreshadowed, another side of this matter,and that is eminently a personal one. The introduction of so large an amount of worrking capital, the value of which to the company at its present juncture we cannot overestimate, has necessarily led to a demand on the part of those finding such capital to acquire the control of the company's directorate. After we had carefully examined our list of shareholders, we came to the conclusion that,with the exception of but a very few- most of whom were resident in Egypt, and directly or indirectly connected with our friend Mr. Nungovich and his group- it would be quite out of the question to ask the shareholders in England to provide the large amount of capital now necessary. We therefore decided to face the music and agree to the demand of the financiers, that upon the firm application for the 100,000 shares being received we, as a board, were prepared to tender our resignations,having previously made such arrangements as would enable the nominees of Mr. Nungovich to join the board. It goes without saying that we dislike vacating the position of trust that you have so long entrusted to us; but we feel that in your own interests there is no other course open to us, more particularly as Mr. Nungovich desires to be in the position, if necessary, to hold the meetings of the directores in Cairo, which would be quite impracticable for the present directors. It has not been officially communicated tous that Mr. Nungovich desires our resignations; but, in view of the recent trend of Egyptian thought, we are inclined to believe that most if not the whole board, will be asked to retie.We cannot for a moment blame Mr. Nungovich for making his own terms, but we do feel a certain regret at the prospect of retiring from the board of a company with whose shareholders in England we have always worked in complete harmony. We are given to understand that the prospectus of the new issure is in a forward state,and we have no hesitation in recommending your acive support to the scheme. The Chairman then moved the adoption of the report.
Mr. J. Bristow seconded the resolution, which was unanimously agreed to, and the dividends as recommended declared.
Mr. J.E. Drower was re-elected a director, and the auditors (Messrs. W.B. Peat and Co.) were reappointed.
An extraordinary general meeting was then held, when thhe resolutions authorising the increase of capital were duly passed.

div.head: KAISER'S NEW NAVY. HUGE BATTLESHIPS &CRUISERS
div.p: Great interest has been aroused by a semi-official statement with regard to the new German naval programme.

The "Kolnische Zeitung" announces that the displacement of the new battleships and armoured cruisers will be 18,000 tons and 15,000 tons respectively. The German Government considers it necessary to follow the example of other navies, which, as the result of the lessons of the Battle of Tsushima, have increased the size of their heavy artillery, thus entailing a corresponding augmentation in the tonnageof the warships.

The Conservative Press welcomes the decision of the Government to bring the navy up to the level of those of other Powers. At present the largest German battleships have a displacement of 13,200 tons, and the displacement of the largest cruisers is 11,000 tons,while the heaviest gun carried is the 28-centimetre (11in.) quick-firer.

The "Tagliche Rundschau" publishes an article by the well-known naval publicist,Count Reventlow,who, while approving the action of the Government, deplores the publication of the programme at the present juncture. He declares that Great Britain has purposely delayed the launchof the first representative of a new type of battleship, in order to obtain as much information as possible with regard to the building programmes of other nations.

div.head: KAISER'S CLEVERNESS IN CHINA.
div.p: An interview with General Yin Chang, the Chinese Minister in Berlin, who is leaving his post to return to China, is published in the "Berliner Tageblatt." General Yin Chang spoke in terms of the highest admiration of the German Emperor,whose proposal to withdraw the foreign garrisons in Pe-chi-li was, he said, an extremely clever diplomati move. The EMperor's proposal had been greeted with great approval in China. General Ying Chang declared, in conclusion, that the Powers made many mistakes in dealing with his country, and were, in many respects, simply driving the Chinese into the arms of Japan. The Japanese were taking part more and more in Chinese commerce, and in the founding of newspapers with the intention of gaining a political influence over the mass of the Chinese population. In his opinion, too, Japan was becoming day by day more subservient to England. Japan's policy was nothing but Great Britain's policy. He regarded England's intention to fortify Singapore as a most important development,the full significance of which was not fully realised in Europe. Great Britain's power and influence in the Far East would be greatly increased by the establishment of a first-class naval base at Singapore.

div.head: NEW YORK LIFE INSURANCE CO
div.p: St. Louis, Nov. 5.

The Insurance Superintendent of Missouri has notified the officials of the NEw York Life Insurance Company that on Tuesday next he will revoke the licence of that company to carry on business in the State owing to the mismanagement of the company's officers as revealed in the investigation at present going on in New York.

This notice is in accordance with the previous intimation given to the company by the Superintendent early last month that this action would be taken unless the implicated officers resigned and the sums paid over to Republican campaign managers were returned.

This is the first action of this kind to be taken, but it is believed that the example will be followed in several other Western States, and that other Eastern insurance companies will be treated in the same manner.

div.p: A prvident wife, says a philosophical contemporary, is an income in herself. But a virtue may be carried to extreme. "Your husband'll be all right now," said the doctor. "What yer mean?" demanded the wife. "You told me he couldn't live a fortnight." "Well, I'm going to cure him after all," said the doctor; "surely you're glad!" The woman wrinkled her brows."Puts me in a bit of an 'ole," she said. "I bin and sold all his clothes for his funeral... Meanin' well. How soon'll 'e be strong?"

div.head: PRIEST BURIED ALIVE. STORY OF SUPERSTITION IN THE CRIMEA.
div.p: The German papers publish a weird story from Seirakrisza in the Crimea.
Owing to the harvest turning out badly the peasants suspected an old man named Opiroff, who was a reputed wizard, to be the cause of the trouble, and seized him.

They prepared a bonfire on the village green, and Opirofi, having been placed upon it, a village elder set the pile alight and burned him to death. As the famine continued it was decided to hold grotesque religious ceremonies over the remains, which were disinterred in accordance with local superstitutions. While these were going on Father Constantine, the village priest, appeared, and rebuked them for their impious barbariam.

The peasants, who were mostly drunk, thereupon declared that he was the evil genius, and seizing him flung him into Opiroff's open grave. Earth was thrown upon him, and he was burid alive by his own parishionners.

div.head: ROME OVERCROWDED
div.p: The tourist who, among his impressions of Rome, has carried away the remembrance of the staring windows of the great empty houses near St. Peter's, and outside the Porta Pia- legacies from the building crisis fo 1887- is astonished to learn that there is difficulty in finding homes for the inhabitants of the great city. The housing question, however, is rapidly becoming a serious one. Since 1870 the population of Rome has more than doubled itself, and since the frantic speculations of the mid-eighties, comparatively few houses have been built, with the exception of villas standing in their own gardens in the new Ludosvisi and Prati di Castello quarters. These are chiefly taken at large rents by the foreign colony, which becomes more and more numerous every year. The destruction of the teeming Ghetto, and of some of the older streets that were removed in order to make room for the tunnel road leading from the via Tritone, has made the houses that remain more sought after, and has crowded the poorer districts of Rome till they are full to overflowing. Four, and even five families in one room is not unknown, and the numbers herded together in one great tenement sometimes rise to four or five hundred.

div.head: THE ARABIAN REVOLT
div.p: Professor Vambery contributes to the current number of the "Contemporary Review" an interesting but short paper on the revolt in Arabia, which, he predicts, will be crushed by the Turks "like the previous one, and like all the revolts of insufficiently armed and undrilled rabbles against a well-armed and fairly organised army." He dismisses as undeserving of credence the rumours circulated in Turkey that the English, anxious to push forward the limits of the Aden Hinterland, are instigating the rising. Professor Vambery disclaims any sympathy for the "nefarious regime" of the present Sultan, but he does not attribute special importance to the present rising: - "The Arabs will never submit complacently to the Turk; they will always despise and hate their foreign ruler; but it would be a mistake to see in this aversion a plan for an Arab national rising against the Ottoman power, and for a restitutiion of the spiritual lead of Islam to the direct descendants of the Prophet. Such a desire may lurk in the distant future, but the present social, cultural and political conditions of the Arab race do not admit of its realisation."

div.head:
Dr. Le Clerc's
Pills for the Liver & Kidneys
div.p: are an unfailing and reliable remedy for diseases of these important organs, gout, rheumatism, gravel pains in the back and kindred ailments (acquired or constitutional). Sold by principal Chemists, not in loose quantities, but only in boxes, price 2s. 3d bearing the British Government Stamp with the words "Eugene Le Clerc" impressed thereon to protect the public from fraud.
Dr. Le Clerc's Soap.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.

L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE est en vente dans les rues du Caire tous les soirs à 7 h.30, excepté les dimanches et jours férieés. Le journal est aussi en vente aux gares du Caire, d'Alexandrie, de Tantah, de Damanhour de Kafr-Zayat et de Zagazig. Prix numéro du jour, 1 P.T.
Les personnes qui connaissent les
Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
5 fr. et 2 fr. 50

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
